title: Tuesday, 2nd October 2018

BE11:11am

The Thomson Reuters Financial & Risk business is now officially Refinitiv, following the closure last night of the private equity deal between Blackstone and Thomson Reuters.

Whereas before you’ve attributed our data in your articles to Thomson Reuters, we would ask that you now please attribute any data you get from us to Refinitiv.

Refinitiv.

Otter Hello friends

........... leaving .... well, leaving basically no money.

TonaldDrump https://www.cosmopolitan.com/uk/entertainment/a23553400/harry-potter-stamps-royal-mail/ They're going to need a bit of magic to get themselves out of this mess.
BE11:19am

Unless Royal Mail's going to be paying its dividend by flogging off property, it's hard to see how the current payout can be sustained.

BE11:19am

Debt, probably.

PBateman Cannot fathom the case for RM renationalisation
Pharma @Ethelred He's planning on expropriating 10% of every listed company, so why would he care about RM holders?
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

PBateman Next day delivery on everything I get 1st class
BE11:19am

Royal Mail's 1H19 warning reveals letter weakness, but primary challenges are on cost inflation and delivery of productivity savings. We lower our 'EBIT before transformation' forecasts broadly in line with the midpoint of new company guidance (£500-550m) for FY19 (now at £528m vs £679m previously), leading to a commensurate mark to market on FCF that we don’t materially repair in our midterm estimates. This leads to our PT falling from 480p to 405p in line with the estimate updates. The updates to our base case valuation drive moves in our Bull & Bear targets, from 660p to 485p and from 335p to 255p.

BE11:20am

While parcels revenue momentum is positive, we believe that ongoing risk to letter mail trends and cost base mitigation challenges mean that margins and cash flows could come under further significant pressure. In addition, parcels growth places pressure on unit cost. We look for strategies on pricing and/or new aggressive cost saving initiatives to gain comfort on margin floors into the medium term. RMG has an attractive portfolio of London property, which it hopes to monetize. However, timing and means of monetization are uncertain.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

And Credit Suisse .....

BE11:21am

Management cited weak business confidence and the impact of GDPR in stating that mail volumes for 1H19E are down 7%. With GDPR introduced on 25 May 2018 and Brexit negotiations ongoing, we model 7% mail volume declines and 5.3% revenue declines for FY19E. With each 1% change in mail revenue worth c.£40m, we persistent revenue declines of 4% or above as extremely challenging. As outlined in Weakening mail & labour costs drive downside, we expect a rate of mail revenue decline of c.4% in the long term – vs the prior c.3% trend

BE11:21am

Royal Mail took £600m of cost out of the business from FY16-FY18, and the market has recognized its track record in this area. However, we believe that management must answer two questions: (i) how it can continue to take £150-200m of cost out of the UK business, with accelerating parcel growth (10% of volumes are automated) and faster letter volume decline (90% automated); (ii) whether FY20E labour cost headwinds of at least c.3.3% (2% wages, 1.3% for the October 2018 reduction in working week) worth c.£165m be offset.

Dec69 - Skeptic Am I missing the obvious of cost inflation, RMG has 37,900 vans and a combination of 7,300 trucks and trailers. Who didn't think costs were skyrocketing, with a move in oil of circa 20%+
11:22 am
BE11:22am

And Caz, which downgrades.

Grouchmonkey Morning all
BE11:22am

Royal Mail’s trading update indicates a worrying combination of accelerating letter volume declines and a vastly reduced rate of cost efficiencies. In our view, management has not provided much evidence for why either of these should improve over time. Royal Mail's dividend cover now does not look sustainable, with our medium-term forecasts suggesting an uncovered dividend. Despite this, management reiterated its intention to pay an increased dividend for FY19e. Given this mix of risks and uninspiring valuation, we have moved to Underweight with a Mar-19 DCF-based 341p price target (previously 537p).

Lawro @Dec69 They're moving to PHEVs a little too late
red If you are worried about labour, RM nationalisation should be the last of your worries!
BE11:23am

And RBC.

DarkKnight morning
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Can they really do an 8% productivity gain by 2020E if 2019E is just 0.1%? With wage increases agreed, plus set potential working week cuts, then over 2019-2020 labour productivity needs to rise around 8%-9% cumulative over the next two years. RMG will now need to run even harder to stand still: Therefore to get back on track, without stamp price increases higher than anticipated, the company will need to work even harder. To us, this is ambitious and we see a high risk that the impact of the present miss becomes hard to claw back from.

BE11:24am

Dividend - continuing to grow by leveraging up - as it now looks more likely FCF outlook comes in lower as consensus profits fall (with an adverse £100m w/cap swing YoY anyway), we think any DPS progression will require more equity to be absorbed by DPS cash outflow. To us, the key question is: Can RMG really catch up and regain the productivity momentum? So far that's not clear to us, and very much a 'show me'. Historically we think mail profit misses prove hard to recover from without offsetting price/revenue actions.

BE11:24am

You get the idea.

PBateman Compensation: Even if ‘nationalisation’ did occur, investors have contractual rights ofcompensation and therefore investors would expect only modest 'hair-cuts’ to portfoliovaluations. HICL stated in November 2017 that the compensation contractually payable inevent of a voluntary termination would be around 96% of the portfolio value at 30/09/17. Wethink the concept of ‘no-compensation’ in a ‘nationalisation’ scenario is not realistic in ademocracy, where legal agreements are in place.
Dec69 - Skeptic Lawro, its a case of analysts not understanding models again. The model is reliant on 6 workshop visits per annum per car. The model is reliant on fluxes in temporary labour which have gone up circa 8% in two years, yet, hidden by costs cuts that can no longer be relied upon.
Pharma @red, if you are not worried about Labour, you have not been paying attention.
Grouchmonkey I see St Ives has a new name. Bob Gavron will be spinning in his grave.
red @Pharmawatching from afar but understand the worries of others that may be caught in the cross fire.
11:25 am

Banks following the trend, with CYBG leading the way.

CYBG PLC (CYBG:LSE): Last: 303.80, down 15.8 (-4.94%), High: 316.40, Low: 303.40, Volume: 967.07k
BE11:30am

Which is on UBS selling.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

We initiate coverage of CYBG with a Sell rating and a 311p price target. CYBG is a challenger bank in the UK (2-5% market share based on company data), focused on Scotland and Northern England. With the UK banking market experiencing an easy credit supply cycle, competition for both loans and deposits is high and CYBG shares common features of the challenger banks: a weak deposit base, declining margins, slowing loan growth and high reliance on BoE funding. This has led the bank to scale up its operations through the acquisition of Virgin Money. In our view, this is unlikely to address these issues, and we forecast declining earnings from FY21e, despite our expectation of deal synergies.

BE11:31am

Oh, forgot to mention last week the arrival of a new challenger bank in the UK ....

BE11:31am

Called ... [checks notes] ..... Goldman Sachs.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

https://www.ft.com.../fintechFT/product

BE11:32am

Goldman Sachs is opening its UK consumer bank on Thursday with an offer of interest rates higher than many rivals, as the US investment banking giant seeks to poach customers from the dominant high street lenders.

Marcus, the first international expansion of Goldman’s new retail business, will offer a 1.5 per cent rate on savings from £1 to £250,000, making it the highest-yielding instant-access account available, according to data company Moneyfacts.

“We’re going out with a strong offer, we know we’ll attract a lot of savers,” Des McDaid, UK managing director of Marcus, said in an interview. “Our goal is not to compete with the small players, the goal is to move people away from the high street banks that control 80 per cent of the market.”

BE11:32am

Raising once again the question we often voice here: what on earth are challenger banks for?

If your family in Glasgow has banked with Clydesdale for about 5 generations and it is the only bank in your area methinks the likelihood of switching is not too great. But what do I know. I am sure UBS visited lots of branches and interviewed customers. Because that is what analysts would do --- right?

Our estimates assume limited conduct costs in 2018e (due to lack of visibility) and our understanding is that no provisions are in place for a new fine. US$1.5bn would be ~55bps of RWAs or ~4% of TBV, leaving CET1 at 14% p/f (all 2H18 p/f). This will still be strong but may raise questions over pace of dividend increase for 2018e (MSe is DPS of 23c in 2018e).

Have some Jefferies:

BE11:56am

[T]he key points we take away are that;
n Gearing falls from c.36% to c.11% on our estimates assuming no further debt issue.
n This provides plenty of headroom for the debt issue BUR alluded to in yesterday's announcement.
n Together with the fund raise we also expect this quarter, and allowing for existing commitments, this implies that BUR sees significant opportunity to deploy capital.
We do not know how big management believes the investment opportunity to be, but we do know that expansion in the US, Australia and Germany is planned. The market will need to think hard about how much capital BUR can deploy over the next year.

hedgehog wasn't there one called juridica ?
BE11:58am

And a bit more, from an earlier note.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

The company had cash balances of $240m at the half year, and this issue could roughly match that number. Existing commitments need to be covered, and BUR expected at the half year for under half its outstanding commitments of $582.5m to be called on within a year. The company also had another $76.6m of other contingent investment exposure, which it did not expect to be drawn unless claims failed. However, in our modelling, capital recycling covers these requirements as well as our new investment assumptions which increased after the half year results. Management states that this capital increase, along with the debt and fund raises, are "business as usual" in terms of managing the company's capital structure, but we do not know what "usual" now is in terms of commitments and investments in this large and under-penetrated market.

undefined
